Award.AwardTitle: Role and Regulation of MAP Kinase Phosphatase 1 as a Negative Regulator of Plant Innate Immune Responses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Extracellular recognition by plants of potential bacterial pathogens initiates rapid changes in plant responses that ultimately lead to restriction of bacterial growth and prevention of disease symptoms. Achievement of the desired outcome of host resistance, however, is a finely balanced process. If the initial host response is not sufficiently rapid or robust, the pathogen overwhelms the host before effective resistance can be achieved. If the response is too strong or lasts for too long, the stress can result in severe fitness penalties (e.g. dwarfing and/or loss of yield) or even cell death. At present, relatively little about is understood about how the initial responses are correctly regulated and integrated to promote resistance. MAP Kinase Phosphatase 1 (MKP1) has been identified as a negative regulator of both the initial phases of host responses and of resistance against pathogenic bacteria. However, unlike most plants with enhanced resistance, the mkp1 mutation prevents bacterial pathogen growth without apparent detrimental effects on the plant's fitness. Therefore, understanding the role and regulation of MKP1 in plant innate immunity will illuminate possible strategies for enhancing resistance against bacteria in crop plants without the fitness penalties normally associated with constitutively enhanced resistance. Genetic, biochemical, and molecular approaches will be used to begin to define the basis for the enhanced resistance in the mkp1 mutant as well as to understand how MKP1 is normally regulated during pathogen infection.

The project will provide advanced training for both a postdoctoral researcher and graduate student as well as for an undergraduate EXPRESS (Exposure to Research for Science Students) student already working in the laboratory, thus providing support for students from a minority group normally underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary and Significance of Research Results

When a potential bacterial pathogen and a potential host plant come into contact, both organisms begin a complex series of responses with the goal of surviving the encounter. Plant recognition of the bacteria triggers rapid responses that ultimately restrict the growth of the bacterial invader, but the mechanism(s) underlying this immunity has been poorly understood. However, at least a portion of this resistance must involve blocking the effectiveness of pathogen virulence program(s). Simultaneously, when bacterial pathogens such as Pseudomonas syringae have access to a suitable host, they initiate virulence programs including the production of a type III secretion system (T3SS). The T3SS produces and injects different bacterial effector proteins into the host cells where they inhibit host defenses and promote the acquisition of nutrients. Although the production of the T3SS is clearly a critical factor in determining the outcome of an infection, the identity of the T3SS-inducing host signals or whether the host can manipulate levels of these signal(s) was not clear.

As a prelude to the research performed during this grant, a unique mutant in the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, was identified that showed enhanced resistance against bacterial pathogens without the detrimental effects (i.e. fitness penalties) normally associated with enhanced immune responses in plants. These results indicated that this mutant that does not produce the protein Mitogen-activated protein Kinase (MAPK) Phosphatase 1 (MKP1) defined a potentially novel mode of resistance. Thus, the goal of this work was to identify the basis of the enhanced resistance in the mkp1 mutant.

In the mkp1 mutant, the bacterial pathogens failed to produce and inject the effector proteins into the plant. These results indicated that the enhanced resistance may be due to the inability of the pathogen to recognize the presence of a potential host and, therefore, switch on its virulence (i.e. infectious) program. This work lead to the identification of five, specific chemicals normally produced by plants that the bacteria utilize to turn on its infectious program. Adding back any of these chemicals restored the ability of the bacteria to inject its proteins and eliminated the resistance in the mutant. These chemicals are present in all plants that were tested, and many different bacterial pathogens were capable of responding to these chemicals. Therefore, this work identified a new layer of resistance in plant pathogen interactions whereby the plant was shown to genetically control the abundance of chemicals utilized by pathogens to recognize its host. Because this chemical recognition strategy appears to be broadly conserved, this work has the potential to translate new strategies for enhancing resistance against bacterial pathogens into field crops.

Broader Impacts

Intellectual Merit: The discovery of a new layer of resistance involving the control of chemical signals utilized by bacterial pathogens to induce their virulence programs provides a previously unexplored strategy for enhancing resistance in the field. Moreover, the discovery of specific chemical signals provides the basis for developing new antimicrobial compounds as it would be hypothetically possible to interfere with the bacteria’s ability to perceive these chemicals, thus preventing from transitioning into its pathogenic state.
